doc.field: The papers relate to property owned by Timothy Cortelyou in Brooklyn and New Utrecht. Folder 1 includes 2 handwritten receipts for advertisements placed by Cortelyou. Folder 2 contains printed facsimiles of documents pertaining land in New Utrecht inherited by Cortelyou from his father, Jaques Cortelyou, upon his death.

The papers relate to property owned by Timothy Cortelyou in Brooklyn and New Utrecht. Folder 1 includes 2 handwritten receipts for advertisements placed by Cortelyou. Folder 2 contains printed facsimiles of documents pertaining land in New Utrecht inherited by Cortelyou from his father, Jaques Cortelyou, upon his death.

The papers relate to property owned by Timothy Cortelyou in Brooklyn and New Utrecht. Folder 1 includes 2 handwritten receipts for advertisements placed by Cortelyou in the Long Island Star. The 1810 advertisement ran for four weeks and announced the sale of property on Front and Washington Streets in Brooklyn. Folder 2 contains printed facsimiles of documents pertaining land in New Utrecht inherited by Cortelyou from his father, Jaques Cortelyou, upon his death. Included are a survey of the land conducted by Jeremiah Johnson, John Lefferts, and Leffert Lefferts. Also included are a map, field notes, and statements of oath. The survey was conducted due to an "Act to Amend" of 1824, giving the United States exclusive jurisdiction to certain lands in New Utrecht. Timothy Cortelyou's children ultimately inherited the land and sold it for subdivision.

Timothy Townsend Cortelyou was born at the Narrows, November 19, 1774 and died May 1, 1829. He was the son of Jaques Cortelyou (1743-1815) and his second wife, Sarah Townsend (1746-1829) of Oyster Bay. Timothy Cortelyou married Anna Kowenhoven on June 23, 1801 and was a member of the New Utrecht Reformed Dutch Church.
Long Island star (Brooklyn, New York, N.Y.)
